column1: Density is a measurement that compares the amount
column2: ratio of matter an object has to its volume. An object with a lot of matter in a certain amount of volume has high density. An object with a little matter in the same amount of volume has a low density.Temperature has an effect on density. When the temperature of a substance increases
column3: density decreases because the atoms are moving all around the place having less matter in one space. When the temperature of a substance decreases
column4: the density increases because the atoms move slower making the atoms stay in one place. Many substances follow this rule
column5: but there are exceptions. Water is one such exception. When water freezes
column6: it makes ice that is less dense than liquid water.Fresh water is often used as a standard of relative density. This is called specific gravity.The most common SI units for density are g/cm3 and kg/m3. When the numerator is much larger than the denominator
column7: that means the substance has a higher density. When the denominator is much larger than the numerator
column8: the substance has a lower density.
